content:
Very interesting, thanks!

Btw, John Conway developed also an algorithm (actually a full Turing complete machine) to generate prime numbers. It’s called FRACTRAN, see https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/FRACTRAN
I guess it suffers from a similar drawback as the method above with the repetition of ones. This program generates indeed a long list of numbers and only those in power of 2 have an prime number exponent. Problem is that for finding large prime number through such exponents, you must wait a very long time before to re observe such a power.

Best,
Laurent

]]>
author: Laurent Jacques
title: By: Laurent Jacques

content:
Hi,
You should also take a look at this draft showing that simple and clever tricks can make gcd algorithms sligthly more efficient for searching primes
http://page.mi.fu-berlin.de/moritz/oeis/cloitre.pdf

]]>
author: Cloitre
title: By: Cloitre

content:
Thanks for mentioning FRACTRAN; I should have included it. Richard Guy wrote an excellent article on Conway’s machine: Mathematics Magazine, Vol. 56, No. 1 (Jan., 1983), pp. 26-33.

]]>
author: Brian Hayes
title: By: Brian Hayes

content:
Thanks much. I had not seen that one.

]]>
author: Brian Hayes
title: By: Brian Hayes

content:
When you take a long hike around the shore of a lake, you eventually wind up exactly where you started, but that does not make the trip worthless. Along the way you may have seen something interesting, or even astonishing.

Yes indeed. On the walk you may discover a river or stream amongst dense trees, that flows into another, bigger or deeper lake.

]]>
author: Reader1
title: By: Reader1

content:
> It seems we are back where we began, and no closer to having a practical prime generator.

I beg to differ: http://www.karllautman.com/primer.html

;-)

author: Karl Lautman
title: By: Karl Lautman
